item.title: What’s this about attacking pirates on land?
item.description: So there was some chatter Friday on my Twitter feed about how EU NAVFOR (the EU’s Naval Forces) would be authorized to attack on land. For example: New EUNAVFOR guidelines allow attacking #pirate targets on late, while #NATO task force stays maritime. #somalia — Jay Bahadur (@PuntlandPirates) March 23, 2012 My thoughts were quickly to escalation. Escalation is important not only for reasons that anyone who feels attacked or invaded would be willing to increase the violence to protect their stuff, but also because Somalis feel incredibly threatened right now.

item.title: Micro-States; Pirates; Terrorists; The London Conference: What a Fascinating Time for Watchers of Somalis
item.description: For almost four years now I’ve been a careful observer of Somali politicians. For three of those years I was paid to try to be their lawyer. To provide them expert international legal assistance tied to a deep network full of some of the finest international practitioners and thinkers in the world. But they rarely, if ever, wanted that help. So largely I invented work, I went into meetings and had a product to sell.

item.title: On The Somali Famine: A Thought Collage
item.description: The original photo is here, my alteration is here. If I had to title the alteration, I would call it An Homage to Motherhood. item.title: On Going Local: Finding Your Happy Place
item.description: On Going Local is a new (short) series that I’ll be running which will attempt to look at my life from an objective perspective as I transition from and NGO worker into an entrepreneur here in the developing world. ![My Happy Place via Lady_k @ flickr]({{ site.url }}{{ site.root }}{{ site.images_dir }}/{{ page.date | date: “%Y” }}/4431206216_8eacda9a75_z.jpg) Photo via Lady_k @ flickr I’ve been here in Somaliland now for around two and a half years now.

item.title: Understanding War [in Mogadishu]
item.description: This week the World Food Program (WFP) shoved out a press release about how piracy was raising food prices in South-Central Somalia. At first glance, most people who would read such a report will likely think, oh the poor people in Mogadishu. Of course, I share their sentiments. However, there is a deeper issue at work here. One that I’m not sure many people realize. The conclusion (because I’m a lawyer and we put these things up front) is that this rise in cost of business may have drastically good effects for the conflict in the South.
